overview.description: The wash sale rule prevents taxpayers from claiming a loss on the sale of stock or securities if they acquire the same or substantially identical stock or securities within a 61-day period.
overview.benefits: Tax-loss harvesting can offset capital gains, but it must be done correctly to avoid disallowed losses.

prohibited_actions: Acquire the same or substantially identical stock or securities
Enter a contract to acquire stock or securities (e.g., call options)
consequences: Disallowed loss from the sale of the original shares
Amount of disallowed loss is added to the basis of the newly acquired shares
Holding period of original shares is added to newly acquired shares

scope: Contracts to acquire stocks or securities
special_cases: Vesting and exercise of compensatory options

triggers: Selling a position in one account and buying it back in another
Selling a position in a taxable account and buying it back in an IRA
Selling at a loss and buying it back in a spouse's account
Selling at a loss and buying it back in a disregarded entity or grantor trust
Selling at a loss and a partnership or corporation buying it back
Acquiring a call option or writing a deep-in-the-money put option on the same position
non_triggers: Waiting 30 days to sell the original position

consultation.note: Always consult your tax advisor before engaging in transactions that might be considered a wash sale.
consultation.services: J.P. Morgan can assist in assessing tax-loss harvesting opportunities but does not provide legal or tax advice.
